title-group.article-title: Primary Extragonadal Germinoma of the Medulla Oblongata

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Pathology, Kansai Rosai Hospital, Amagasaki, Hyogo, Japan
2Department of Neurosurgery, Kansai Rosai Hospital, Amagasaki, Hyogo, Japan
3Department of Radiology, Kansai Rosai Hospital, Amagasaki, Hyogo, Japan
4Department of Neurosurgery, Kitano Hospital, Osaka, Japan

author-notes.corresp: Shin-ichi Nakatsuka, Department of Pathology, Kansai Rosai Hospital, 3-1-69 Inabaso, Amagasaki, Hyogo 660-8511, Japan Email: nakatsuka@kanrou.net

abstract.p: Extragonadal germ cell tumors rarely arise from the brain stem. In this report, the authors present a rare case of germinoma developing in the medulla oblongata. A 31-year-old woman complained of intractable hiccups, hoarseness, and swallowing disturbance. Magnetic resonance imaging showed a tumor located on the dorsal part of the medulla oblongata without any abnormalities in the pineal body and suprasellar regions. Histological diagnosis of surgically resected tumor was germinoma. Tumor cells were positive for alkaline phosphatase, c-kit, octamer-binding transcription factor 3/4, cytokeratin, and epithelial membrane antigen in immunohistochemistry. The patient received adjuvant chemotherapy and irradiation to the residual tumor and cerebral ventricles. The patient is alive without recurrence 6 months after the surgery.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Extragonadal germ cell tumors rarely develop in the central nervous system (CNS), accounting for 2% to 3% of all CNS neoplasms.1 Germinoma is the most common histological subtype of the CNS germ cell tumors.2 Intracranial germ cell tumors preferentially arise from pineal body and suprasellar lesion, whereas brain stem is rarely involved. In this report, we present a young female patient with primary germinoma of the medulla oblongata and review 13 cases in the literature.3-14

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: A 31-year-old woman with a 1-year history of intractable hiccups, discomfort in her throat, and hoarseness was referred to our hospital. Her symptoms gradually worsened and she showed swallowing disturbance. She showed no endocrinological abnormalities. On admission, she was alert, and a neurological examination showed no cranial nerve deficits other than frequent hiccups, swallowing disturbance, and hoarseness. She did not show dysarthria and dyspnea. Gag reflex was maintained. Weakness and sensory disturbance of her upper and lower extremities was not observed. Laboratory data were within normal limits. Serum levels of tumor markers were not evaluated. Magnetic resonance imaging showed a 12 × 8 × 8 mm3 tumorous lesion located on the dorsal part of the medulla oblongata caudal to the fourth ventricle (Figure 1). The tumor showed isointensity in T1- and T2-weighted images with slight contrast enhancement. There were no abnormalities in the pineal body, hypothalamus, and neurohypophysis. Tumor dissemination to the ventricles and spinal cord was not observed. For the purpose of histological diagnosis and debulking, subtotal resection of the tumor was performed. A poorly demarcated, grayish-white tumor was observed on the floor of the fourth ventricle. The postoperative histological diagnosis was germinoma. Histologically tumor consisted of sheets and solid nests of large polygonal epithelioid cells with abundant clear cytoplasm (Figure 2A). The nuclei of the tumor cells included coarse chromatin with prominent centrally located nucleoli. Syncytiotrophoblastic giant cells were not observed. Mitotic figures were observed at a frequency of 10 per 10 high-power fields. Many small lymphocytes had infiltrated around tumor nests, presenting the so-called 2-cell pattern. By immunohistochemical analysis, the tumor cells were positive for placental alkaline phosphatase (Figure 2B), c-kit (Figure 2C), octamer-binding transcription factor (OCT) 3/4 (Figure 2D), cytokeratin, and epithelial membrane antigen and were negative for glial fibrillary acidic protein, leukocyte common antigen, S-100, vimentin, α-fetoprotein, hCG subunit β, and CD30. No other components of germ cell tumors were observed. After the surgery, the patient was administered chemotherapy with etoposide and carboplatin and radiotherapy with 24 Gy of irradiation to the residual tumor and cerebral ventricles. Her neurological symptoms were markedly improved, and she is alive without recurrence of the disease 6 months after the surgery.

caption.p: Preoperative magnetic resonance imaging of the brain

(A) The horizontal plane of T2-weighted image shows a tumor located on the dorsal part of the medulla oblongata. (B) The sagittal plane of T1-wighted image with contrast medium shows a slightly enhanced tumor caudal to the fourth ventricle (arrow).

(A) Large polygonal tumor cells with abundant cytoplasm and prominent nucleoli clustered. Infiltration of small lymphocytes was seen (hematoxylin and eosin staining, original magnification 400×). (B-D) Immunohistochemistry for placental alkaline phosphatase (B), c-kit (C), and OCT 3/4 (D). Tumor cells showed positivity for placental alkaline phosphatase, c-kit, and OCT 3/4 (original magnification 400×).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Extragonadal germ cell tumors of CNS preferentially arise in the middle plane in location such as the pineal body and suprasellar region. Germinoma arising from the medulla oblongata is extremely rare and to our knowledge, only 14 cases (1983-2010),3-14 including the present one have been reported in the English and Japanese literature. The 14 patients were 12 to 40 years old with an average of 24.3 years, which is slightly older than that for all other intracranial germinoma patients (average 18.1 years2). Ten patients were female and 4 were male, including 1 with Klinefelter syndrome.6 The most frequent symptoms were lower cranial nerve disturbances such as swallowing disturbance, hiccups, hoarseness, absence of gag reflex, and weakness and deviation of the tongue, which was observed in 10 of 14 cases. Cerebellar signs such as nystagmus and ataxia were observed in 11 cases. Two patients showed apnea.6,13 Four patients showed hydrocephalus with increased intracranial pressure.3,4,9,12 In histology, syncytiotrophoblastic giant cells were detected in only 1 case.8 All patients underwent a biopsy or a resection followed by radiation and/or chemotherapy. Twelve of 13 patients had no recurrence, and 10 patients were alive after follow-up periods of 2 months to 9 years. Three patients died of other diseases after follow-up periods ranging from 3 weeks to 13 months.

Immunohistochemical analysis using specific markers is essential for the definitive diagnosis of germinoma. Placental alkaline phosphatase and c-kit are useful as immunohistochemical markers for germinoma. Recently, the utility of the homeodomain transcription factors as specific markers for germinoma have been reported. OCT3/4 and NANOG, which maintain embryonic stem cell self-renewal and pluripotency, are highly specific and sensitive markers for germinoma and are superior to placental alkaline phosphatase in the diagnosis of CNS germinoma.15,16 Histological diagnosis of intracranial germinoma is usually simple, but accurate diagnosis of germinoma may sometimes be difficult when the tumor develops at an age and location that are not typical for germinomas.

Because of the limited number of cases, treatment of germinoma of the medulla oblongata has not been established yet. Platinum-based chemotherapy such as EP (etoposide, cisplatin/carboplatin) and ICE (ifosfamide, cisplatin, etoposide) are used as first-line regimen of adjuvant chemotherapy. Because chemotherapy alone cannot prevent the tumor from relapsing,17 reduced-dose radiation therapy covering the cerebral ventricles in conjunction with chemotherapy is recommended.17,18
